Occasionally,	 customers	 do	not	receive	 their	full	benefits,	 more	often	
than	 not	because	 they	 have	 forgotten	 to	update	 their	 contact	
information.	 AEGON	 is	committed	 to	tracing	 all	beneficiaries	 and	
ensuring	 they	receive	 their	full	entitlements.	 AEGON	 companies	 use	a	
number	 of	techniques,	 ranging	 from	 the	more	 straightforward	 	
–	consulting	 telephone	 directories	 and	government	 registers	 –	to	
more	 advanced	 online	 searches	 and	placing	 advertisements	 in	
newspapers	and	other	publications.
Overall,	 AEGON	 estimates	 that,	in	its	three	 established	 markets	 of	the	
United	 States,	 the	Netherlands	 and	the	United	 Kingdom,	 some	 17,000	
eligible	 beneficiaries	 did	not	initially	 claim	 their	entitlements	 in	2006,	
a	small	 percentage	 of	the	company’s	 total	customer	 base	of	more	
than	40	million.	 In	the	United	 Kingdom,	 approximately	 a	third	of	these	
customers	initially	listed	as	uncontactable	were	successfully	traced.	The	marketplace	 	AEGON’S	markets;	Managing	customer	relations
In	the	Netherlands,	 the	proportion	 was	higher,	 at	50	percent.	 In	the	
United	 States,	 AEGON	 has	taken	 a	number	 of	measures	 to	help	trace	
customers	who	do	not	claim	their	entitlements.	While	 AEGON	 does	its	best	to	contact	 all	customers,	 there	is	inevitably	
a	number	 who	cannot	 be	traced.	 In	the	United	 States,	 the	Netherlands	
and	the	United	 Kingdom,	 AEGON	 ensures	 benefits	 and	entitlements	
for	these	 customers	 remain	 available	 for	as	long	as	possible.	 In	the	
United	 States,	 which	 has	the	highest	 number	 of	such	customers,	 all	
benefits	 remain	 in	policyholders’	 accounts	 and	are	not	added	 to	the	
company’s	 income.	 In	the	Netherlands,	 customers	 never	 lose	their	
right	to	claim,	 no	matter	 how	many	 years	 lapse.	 In	the	United	 Kingdom,	
meanwhile,	 benefits	 are	transferred	 to	an	external	 fund	only	when	
absent	policyholders	reach	the	age	of	75.	Detective	work:	AEGON’s	team	in	the	Netherlands	ensures	that	as	much	money	as	possible	goes	to	its	rightful	owner.
